section.name: User Management
section.p: The default user manager is configured via the file hermesftp-users.xml. This XML file contains the information about all ftp user groups, their resource consumption limits and permissions granted on data folders. It contains also a list of all users known to the system.

subsection.name: Group Configuration
subsection.p: Users of the same group share similar permissions and resource constraints. You can configure as many groups as you like. However, we recommend that you configure at least two: users and administrators. A user group contains information about resource consumption limits and access permissions all group members a subjected to.

Each resource consumption limit has a name and a value (see code snippet). Currently, there a four limits supported:
Bytes downloaded: Number of bytes the user is allowed to download per day.
Bytes uploaded: Number of bytes the user is allowed to upload per day.
Files downloaded: Number of files the user is allowed to download per day.
Files uploaded: Number of files the user is allowed to upload per day.
Download rate: Maximum data transfer rate in KB/s (download stream).
Upload rate: Maximum data transfer rate in KB/s (upload stream).

Each group contains a list permissions granted on ftp data folders. The folders are specified using ANT style patterns. You can read more about these patterns here. There two placeholders that can be included in path names: ${ftproot} corresponds to the setting ftp.root.dir in the application context file hermesftp-ctx.xml and points to the root ftp folder. The expression ${user} is replaced by the user name dynamically. A permission level is assigned to each of the path patterns:
r: Read only access.
rw: Read/writeaccess.
The following code snippet demonstrates a typical group configuration:
subsection.source: <groups> <group name="users" > <limits> <limit name="Bytes downloaded" value="1000000"/> <limit name="Bytes uploaded" value="1000000"/> <limit name="Files downloaded" value="100"/> <limit name="Files uploaded" value="100"/> <limit name="Download rate" value="-1"/> <limit name="Upload rate" value="-1"/> </limits> <permissions> <permission flag="rw" path="${ftproot}/${user}/**"/> <permission flag="rw" path="${ftproot}/${user}"/> <permission flag="r" path="${ftproot}"/> </permissions> </group> ... </groups>

subsection.name: User Configuration
subsection.p: Only users that are known to the application are granted access to the data folders. Each user is configured along with his/her login name, fullname, and password. A user may be member of different groups.

The user's password can be configured in plain text or as hashcode calculated by an supported algorithm. The name of the algorithm is prepended to a BASE64 encoded string, e.g. "{MD5}Cwz8B/yoHJVquRgdhXb0qA==". If the password does not start with a curly brace, it is handled as plain text. Since Hermes FTP servers comes without GUI, the password hash is generated from the command line as follows:
java -jar hermesftp-<version>.jar -password <secretpassword> <algorithm>
Example:
c:\develop>java -jar hermesftp-0.2.jar -password sec MD5 Hash: {MD5}dEWco8+FqB35Dalf9ueiBw== c:\develop>
The following code snippet demonstrates a typical user configuration:
subsection.source: <users default-dir="${ftproot}/${user}"> <user uid="user" fullname="Test User" password="user"> <group-ref name="users"/> </user> <user uid="admin" fullname="Administrator" adminrole="true" password="{MD5}dEWco8+FqB35Dalf9ueiBw=="> <group-ref name="users"/> <group-ref name="administrators"/> </user> </users>
subsection.p: You can omit the password to enable anonymous login (An email address is expected as password).
